title: Are there some super cheap brush pens in China that are good enough for beginners wanting to experiment with calligraphy? - Quora

response.answer_text: Chinese calligraphy brushes run the full price range, from 10 RMB (in China) to as much as you would like to pay! In the US I buy brushes for about $6.00 for my beginning students to use. The absolutely cheapest brushes available are probably not the best, but price is not an essential indicator of quality when selecting a calligraphy brush. Unfortunately, some brushes work well, but in order to produce them cheaply, they soon fall apart. It won’t affect your calligraphy, but you won’t own a functional brush for long. My recommendation is that you buy a brush from a reputable seller, or have someone knowledgeable help you with your selection. It is difficult to describe the qualities of a good brush, but easy to tell when you see one. As for the brush pen you refer to, there are brush markers available for a dollar or less. The quality of these is more uniform. The advantage of a brush marker is that like any other marker it already has ink, doesn’t have any danger of spillage and is therefore easier to take with you and use anywhere. Bottom line: price should be no obstacle to getting started with calligraphy. Perfectly reasonable brushes are available for a very tiny investment!

If you are still a beginner, you might also want to look for 水寫布 shuǐxiěbù/shoeishieebuh, a kind of reusable cloth that lets you write characters using plain water.  [水寫布 Shuǐxiěbù / shoeishieebuh literally “water writing cloth” with squares arranged in a 3x3 pattern 九宮格 jiǔgōnggé/jeougongger] As soon as the water from a brush touches the cloth, it turns dark. As the water dries up, the characters fade away, so the cloth is reusable. Four Advantages: (1) There is no ink to stain your hands, your clothes etc. (2) You don’t waste tons of paper that you will definitely throw away (3) You don’t have to be constantly reminded that your characters don’t look right. You can try again and again (4) Not using ink produces less wear and tear on brushes, so they will last longer, too. No need for rinsing!

Just visit any stationery shop in China, and they sell the brush. Robert’s suggestion is very practical and helpful. You can ask your friend to buy you one from Taobao, at the price about RMB20, including a basic brush.
